Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: THE MCMURDO DRY VALLEYS: A landscape on the Threshold of Change
Award.AbstractNarration:
Collaborative Research: THE MCMURDO DRY VALLEYS: A Landscape on the Threshold of Change is supported by the Antarctic Integrated System Science (AISS) program in the Antarctic Sciences Section of the Division of Polar Programs within the Geosciences Directorate of the National Sciences Foundation (NSF). The funds will support the collection of state-of-the-art high resolution LIDAR (combining the terms light and radar) imagery of the Dry Valleys of Antarctica in the 2014/2015 Antarctic field season, with LIDAR data collection and processing being provided by the NSF-supported NCALM (National Center for Airborne Laser Mapping) facility. LIDAR images collected in 2014/2015 will be compared to images from 2001 in order to detect decadal change. Additional fieldwork will look at the distribution of buried massive ice, and the impacts that major changes like slumping are having on the biota. All field data will be used to improve models on energy balance, and hydrology.

Intellectual Merit: There have been dramatic changes over the past decade in the McMurdo Dry Valleys: glaciers are deflating by tens of meters, rivers are incising by more than three meters, and thermokarst slumps are appearing near several streams and lakes. These observations have all been made by researchers in the field, but none of the changes have been mapped on a valley-wide scale. This award will provide a new baseline map for the entire Dry Valley system, with high-resolution imagery provided for the valley floors, and lower resolution imagery available for the higher elevation areas that are undergoing less change. The project will test the idea that sediment-covered ice is associated with the most dramatic changes, due to differential impacts of the increased solar radiation on sediment-covered compared to clean ice, and despite the current trend of slightly cooling air temperatures within the Dry Valleys. Information collected on the topography, coupled with the GPR determined buried ice distributions, will also be incorporated into improved energy and hydrological models. In addition to providing the new high-resolution digital elevation model (DEM), the project will ultimately result in identification of areas that are susceptible to sediment-enhanced melt-driven change, providing a powerful prediction tool for the impacts of climate change.

Broader Impacts: The new DEM will be immediately useful to a wide range of disciplines, and will provide a comprehensive new baseline against which future changes will be compared. The project will provide a tool for the whole community to use, and the investigators will work with the community to make them aware of the new assets via public presentations, and perhaps via a workshop. The map will have international interest, and will also serve as a tool for environmental managers to draw on as they consider conservation plans. Several undergraduate and graduate students will participate in the project, and one of the co-PIs is a new investigator. The imagery collected is expected to be of interest to the general public in addition to scientific researchers, and venues for outreach such as museum exhibits and the internet will be explored. The proposed work is synergistic with 1) the co-located McMurdo LTER program, and 2) the NCALM facility that is also funded by the Geosciences Directorate.

POR.DRECONTENT:
How stable is permafrost in Antarctica’s “deep freeze”? How quickly will Antarctic coastal regions experience ice loss, slumping, and melting like that facing the arctic today? What is causing permafrost to melt in Antarctica. The goal of our project was to answer these questions using repeat laser scanning from an airborne LiDAR system.

We measured landscape change in the McMurdo Dry Valleys (MDV) in order to predict future changes by identifying components of the cold desert landscape that are most susceptible to melt-driven change. We surveyed the surface elevation of the MDV in detail using an airborne LiDAR scanner. This high resolution topographic map was compared to a 2001 survey to show where melting and erosion have occurred at an unprecedented spatial scale. This was the first time in over a decade that a high-resolution topographic map of the had been produced. During that time, microclimate conditions in the MDV have changed—emerging from a local cooling trend to a period of warm, low-cloud, summers.

Repeat LiDAR has revealed the presence of widespread changes to the MDV at the landscape scale: deep incision of streams into buried ice, thermokarst pond (melt pool) formation and expansion, roughening and thinning of glacier surfaces, and the potential for an overall transition from water storage in ice to water storage in streams, lakes, runoff, and groundwater. In places, over 1 million cubic meters of ice had melted away in the space of ~13 years, forming large cliffs, deep chasms, and changes to the soil ecosystem downstream.

The largest gross volume losses are observed in areas with buried ice (e.g., Alph Lake in the Ross Sea Drift, Garwood Valley). The same is true for fastest erosion rates.  What connects many of the largest erosion sites is the presence of nearby buried ice deposits revealed with ground penetrating radar. One key result from the project is that where buried ice is present (from ancient glaciers and ice sheets or from more recent freezing and thawing), there is a large risk for melting and destabilization of the ground surface. While most melt observed in this study is occurring near the Ross Sea coast, the risk of melting and subsidence extends inland and to higher elevations—to areas once considered “stable” and “frozen.”

            Rapid and large scale formation of melt pools and ice-eroded stream channels suggests that large portions of the MDV may be experiencing a transition to Arctic-like surface processes, where melting leads to changes in how energy enters and leaves the ground, which drives more melting. This melting and landscape collapse potentially threatens US infrastructure along the coast, including McMurdo Station and its satellite facilities (such as Marble Point, Black Island, etc.). Buried ice is common in these locations, providing the possibility of melting leading instabilities in coastal infrastructure similar to that occurring in arctic coastal regions.

            Scientifically, the melting “hotspots” observed in this study are harbingers of more widespread landscape change in Antarctica, as permafrost thaws, glaciers melt, and pond and lake levels rise. Melting of permafrost in Antarctica results in the loss of useful climate records in the form of sediment deposits and landforms that help scientists reconstruct the rates of past climate change. Thaw also means wetting of Antarctic soils, potentially leading to changes in the microbial populations that live in Antarctic habitats.
